## 1️⃣ Feedback on Your Answer  

**Great effort for trying to recall the rule!** 🎉  
You wrote:

\[
\text{Sum of interior angles} = (n+2)\times 180^\circ
\]

where *n* is the number of sides.  
That **doesn’t give the right answer** – the formula for any polygon is actually  

\[
\boxed{\text{Sum of interior angles} = (n-2)\times 180^\circ}
\]

### Why the “‑2” instead of “+2”?

Think about the simplest polygon you know – a **triangle**.  
A triangle has 3 sides, and we all know its interior angles add up to \(180^\circ\).

\[
(3-2)\times180^\circ = 1\times180^\circ = 180^\circ \qquad\text{✓}
\]

If we used “+2”, we would get  

\[
(3+2)\times180^\circ = 5\times180^\circ = 900^\circ,
\]

which is obviously far too large. The “‑2” comes from the fact that any polygon can be divided into \((n-2)\) triangles (by drawing diagonals from one vertex). Each triangle contributes \(180^\circ\), so we multiply by the number of triangles.

### Applying the correct formula to a pentagon  

A pentagon has \(n = 5\) sides.

\[
\text{Sum} = (5-2)\times180^\circ = 3\times180^\circ = 540^\circ .
\]

So the interior angles of a pentagon add up to **\(540^\circ\)**, not \(1260^\circ\).
